text: seeing firsthand a testament of what one
city has endured this is where the
conflict has been at its fiercest before
the war fifty thousand people lived here
in the last 18 months sada has become a
key battleground the heart of the Houthi
rebellion and the target of more
airstrikes than any other Yemeni city
this was once Saudis busiest market
hundreds of people used to make a living
here selling sweets food clothes and now
it's completely destroyed they fled
leaving everything behind we visit the
nearby school it's been damaged by an
air strike the headmaster tells me he's
afraid it will happen again next door is
something the Saudis would consider
target who'd the arms depo he's
repeatedly begged them to move it but
even if the school moves the weapons
will follow with no hope of the conflict
ending soon and despite the dangers the
children have returned to their classes
they tell me their stories the things
they've seen in this war Saleh was in
his bedroom he says he heard the fighter
jets above moments later the strike hit
his home we were lucky my family escaped
he says but we lost everything
I miss my bicycle most these stories are
all too familiar Muhammad also lost his
home along with his uncle he takes me to
see what's left of where he grew up we
were born here we lived here
look at these houses they tell their own
story under six months after losing
their home
[ __ ] lost his father we obtained
footage of the attack from a local
journalist as an ambulance driver
Muhammad's father rushed to the scene of
this airstrike as he dragged the wounded
from the rubble another airstrike hit a
so-called DoubleTap the boy's father and
17 other people were instantly killed
the UN have condemned the use of these
DoubleTap airstrikes in Yemen and said
the targeting of rescue workers amounts
to a war crime the Houthis are not
blameless the UN accuses them of using
civilians for cover they've also been
launching missiles from Sadr into Saudi
Arabia in May 2015 the saudi-led
coalition declared sada a military zone
this violated the laws of war which
prohibit the grouping of a number of
military targets as one also meant that
they no longer distinguish between
combatants and civilians according to
the United Nations the first wave of
airstrikes destroyed 1,200 structures
amongst them five markets a petrol
station and 27 members of one family
were killed in their home off the city
have now fled their homes in search of
safety the women show me where they've
been targeted
but with airports closed and borders
blocked they have nowhere else to go
they've lost everything even their hope
for the future
no Alan McAfee BBC news sada
